name: Moambe
description: An emblematic and rich dish from Central African cuisine. It consists of chicken simmered in a creamy, flavorful sauce made from palm nut pulp oil (Moambe).
recipe: Salt, pepper, and season the chicken pieces (nutmeg, paprika).
In a large pot, heat half of the oil. Brown the chicken on all sides, then remove and set aside.
In the same pot, add the remaining oil and sauté the sliced onions until translucent (approximately 5 minutes).
Add the minced garlic and grated ginger. Cook for 1 minute.
Stir in the tomato paste and diced tomatoes, mix, and simmer for 5 minutes.
Return the chicken to the pot. Add the broth, salt, and spices (chili flakes if used). Bring to a boil, then cover and simmer over low heat for 20 minutes.
Meanwhile, dissolve the Moambe paste or peanut butter in a little hot sauce taken from the pot until a homogeneous sauce is obtained.
Pour the Moambe/peanut mixture into the pot, stir gently, and continue to simmer for an additional 10 minutes, until the sauce thickens and the chicken is fully cooked.
If the sauce is too fatty (especially with Moambe), skim and remove the excess oil before serving with rice or saka-saka.

name: Bobolo (Manioc Stick)
description: A traditional and fermented accompaniment from Central Africa, consisting of manioc (cassava) paste conditioned into firm, steamed sticks, wrapped in banana leaves.
recipe: Peel and wash the manioc tubers thoroughly.
Soak the manioc in clean, cold water for 4 days, changing the water daily. The manioc must become soft and fermented (essential process to reduce cyanide content).
Remove the tubers from the water, drain them, open them, and remove the central fiber (the stringy part).
Crush or grind the fermented manioc to obtain a homogeneous paste.
Press the paste in a clean cloth to eliminate the excess water and starch.
Divide the paste into portions and shape them into regular rolls (sticks).
Wrap each paste stick in one or more banana leaves (or substitute wrapping) to form an airtight package.
Steam the sticks in a pot for 90 minutes to 120 minutes, until they are firm and tender. (The duration depends on the size of the sticks).
Serve hot or cold, sliced.

name: Kwanga (Chikwangue)
description: A Congolese staple food, very similar to Bobolo. It is a block or stick of fermented and steamed manioc (cassava) paste, conditioned and served wrapped in banana or marantaceae leaves. Its texture is often more gelatinous than Bobolo.
recipe: Prepare the fermented manioc paste: Soak the manioc tubers in water for 7 days to 14 days (depending on the method) to achieve fermentation and softening.
Remove the manioc from the water, peel it, and blend/pound it to obtain a very fine paste.
Press and drain the paste to remove the water and fibers.
Cook a small portion of the paste in boiling water until a gelatinous mass is obtained (like a Placali).
Mix this cooked portion with the rest of the raw paste to bind it and give it its characteristic texture.
Wrap the resulting paste in banana leaves (or other) to form thick sticks or blocks.
Steam in a pot (bain-marie) for 60 minutes until the Kwanga is compact and gelatinous.
Serve hot or at room temperature.

name: Liboke de Poisson (Fish Liboke)
description: A Congolese specialty where fish is braised in a pouch made of banana leaves, which gives the dish a unique fragrance and preserves the aromas of the spices.
ingredients: Fish (catfish, tilapia, or carp) cut into pieces
Chili pepper (whole or chopped, to taste)
recipe: Clean the fish with lemon juice or vinegar to remove the sliminess, rinse, and dry the pieces.
Prepare the marinade: In a bowl, mix the onions, garlic, ginger, tomatoes, chives, salt, pepper, bouillon cube, and oil.
Generously coat the fish pieces with this marinade.
On a flat surface, lay out a large banana leaf (possibly doubled). Place half of the marinade in the center.
Arrange the fish pieces on this marinade base, then cover with the rest of the marinade and a whole chili pepper (if used).
Close the banana leaf to form an airtight package (the *Liboké*). Tie if necessary with string or secure with aluminum foil.
Steam (in a large pot with water at the bottom, bain-marie) or bake (in a dish with a little water at the bottom) for approximately 60 minutes.
Serve hot, directly in the pouch or unwrapped on a plate, traditionally with manioc or rice.

name: Couscous Royal
description: A traditional Berber dish, emblematic of the Maghreb, consisting of steamed durum wheat semolina served with a stew (tafaya) of vegetables and several types of meat (lamb, chicken, beef/merguez in the "royal" version).
recipe: Stew preparation: In the bottom part of the couscoussier or a large Dutch oven, brown the lamb and chicken pieces in olive oil.
Remove the meat and sweat the sliced onion. Add the celery, carrots, and turnips. Sauté for a few minutes.
Stir in the Ras el Hanout, paprika, and tomato paste. Return the meat. Salt and pepper.
Cover with water (or broth) and bring to a boil. Simmer for 45 minutes.
Add the zucchini cut into large cubes and the drained chickpeas. Continue cooking the stew for 15 minutes.
Semolina preparation: Pour the semolina into a large dish. Add olive oil and salt. Rub it by hand to separate the grains.
Moisten the semolina with an equal amount of boiling water (or broth). Cover and let it swell for 5 minutes.
Fluff the semolina with a fork to separate the grains. (For a traditional couscoussier, steam the semolina above the stew, repeating the operation three times).
Grill the merguez in a pan or on a grill, without adding fat.
Serving: Arrange the semolina in a dome, dig a well for the vegetables and broth. Garnish with the different pieces of meat (lamb, chicken, merguez) and sprinkle with fresh coriander.

name: Chicken Tagine with Preserved Lemon and Olives
description: An emblematic Moroccan dish, cooked slowly in an earthenware pot of the same name. It is a chicken stew, flavored by the tangy taste of preserved lemon, the salty notes of green olives, and a blend of mild spices (saffron, ginger).
ingredients: Chopped fresh coriander and flat-leaf parsley
recipe: Prepare the marinade: Mix the olive oil, ginger, turmeric, garlic, saffron, salt, and pepper. Coat the chicken pieces and let them marinate for 30 minutes.
Cut the preserved lemon: Dice the pulp and peel, removing the seeds.
In a tagine dish or Dutch oven, brown the marinated chicken pieces on all sides. Remove and set aside.
Add the sliced onions to the pot and sweat them gently for 5 minutes. Add the remaining marinade spices (if any).
Return the chicken to the dish. Add the broth, cover, and simmer for 45 minutes over low heat.
Add the diced preserved lemon, rinsed green olives, and half of the chopped fresh herbs.
Cover again and simmer for 15 minutes, until the chicken is very tender.
Check the seasoning (preserved lemon and olives are salty).
Serve hot, garnished with the remaining fresh herbs, often accompanied by semolina.

name: Egg Brik
description: A crispy and popular specialty of the Maghreb, particularly in Tunisia. It consists of a brik pastry sheet (or malsouka) folded into a half-moon or triangle, stuffed with a filling (potato, tuna, parsley) and a raw egg, then quickly fried for a runny yolk.
recipe: Prepare the filling: Mash the cooked potatoes. Mix with the crumbled tuna, parsley/coriander, chopped onion, capers, salt, and pepper. (Optional: sauté the onion beforehand).
Assembly: Lay a brik sheet flat. Place the filling in the center.
Make a small well in the middle of the filling and crack a raw egg into it (do not mix it with the filling).
Gently fold the edges of the brik sheet to form a triangle, half-moon, or square (making sure the egg is contained and the sheet is tightly sealed).
Frying: Heat the oil generously in a pan over high heat (it must be very hot).
Gently place the brik in the oil. Fry for 1 minute on each side, until golden brown and crispy.
Remove the brik and drain it on paper towels.
Serve immediately while the egg yolk is still runny, with a lemon wedge.

name: Chorba (or Tchorba) Algerian Style
description: A thick and very fragrant traditional soup from the Maghreb, essential during Ramadan. It is generally based on meat (lamb), various vegetables, tomatoes, and spices, enriched with vermicelli or crushed wheat.
ingredients: Lamb meat (neck or shoulder) cut into small cubes
Ripe peeled and diced tomatoes or crushed tomatoes
recipe: In a large pot (marmite), heat the olive oil. Add the chopped onion, garlic, and celery, and sauté for 5 minutes.
Add the lamb pieces and brown them on all sides.
Stir in the spices (Ras el Hanout, paprika, cumin), diced tomatoes, and tomato paste. Mix well and cook for 5 minutes.
Add the hard vegetables (carrots, turnips) and soaked chickpeas. Cover with water or broth. Salt and pepper.
Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 30 minutes.
Add the diced zucchini and continue cooking for 15 minutes.
Add the vermicelli (or crushed wheat) 10 minutes before the end of cooking, stirring to prevent sticking.
Taste and adjust the seasoning. When serving, generously sprinkle with fresh chopped coriander and mint.

name: Mafé (Chicken with Peanut Butter)
description: A rich and flavorful stew, popular in West Africa. The meat (beef or chicken) is simmered in a creamy and smooth sauce based on peanut paste, tomato paste, and root vegetables.
ingredients: Chicken or beef cut into pieces
recipe: Brown the seasoned meat pieces (salt, pepper, garlic/ginger if desired) in a large Dutch oven with oil. Remove and set aside.
In the same Dutch oven, sauté the sliced onions until translucent.
Add the minced garlic and grated ginger. Cook for 1 minute.
Stir in the tomato paste, mix, and cook for 5 minutes to 'break' the acidity.
Dilute the peanut paste in a little hot broth until a smooth texture is obtained.
Pour the peanut mixture into the Dutch oven. Stir vigorously to avoid lumps.
Add the rest of the broth and the reserved meat. Bring to a boil and simmer for 15 minutes.
Add the carrots, potatoes, and sweet potato cut into large pieces. Place the whole chili pepper if used.
Cover and simmer over low heat for approximately 60 minutes, until the sauce is thick and the meat and vegetables are very tender.
Stir occasionally to prevent the sauce from sticking. Remove the chili pepper and serve hot with white rice.
